div.head: An Admonition to the Reader, concerning the Reply of T. F. &c.
div.p:
1 THis Decree of the Sacred Congregation, as it is thus tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh, I haue (Courteous Reader) taken out of M. T. F. lately publi≈øhed, who≈øe
vn≈øound, and in≈øufficient handling this Controuer≈øie, but yet ≈øomewhat cunning, and colourable, and therefore ea≈øie to blinde the eyes of the ≈øimple, I will, God willing, ere it be long mo≈øt clearely, but mode≈øtly di≈øcouer. In the meane time, thou maie≈øt very plainely perceiue the weakne≈ø≈øe of his Di≈øcour≈øe (to omit his intemperate and vncharitable bitterne≈ø≈øe) if thou do≈øt but con≈øider the true ≈øtate of the Controuer≈øie, which is betwixt vs, and that all his Replies mu≈øt be either euident demon≈øtrations, or inuincible authorities, to which no probable an≈øwer can be giuen, otherwi≈øe he onely beateth about the bu≈øh, and will neuer prooue that which he pretended to conuince; and wilt al≈øo be plea≈øed but ≈øleightly to reade ouer the Appendix to my Theologicall Di≈øputation, wherein I fully an≈øwered all the arguments, which Fa: Suarez bringeth to demon≈øtrate the doctrine for the Popes power to depo≈øe Princes to be a point of faith; which Doctrine as this Authour confe≈ø≈øeth, is the maine que≈øtion between him and me: and therefore for the better confirmation of his Reply, hee nakedly vrgeth all Fa: Suarez arguments (but
concealing his name) which I in that Appendix haue already fully ≈øatisfied.

2 For fir≈øt, I plainely declared the rea≈øon of that di≈øtinction, which I alledged betwixt the Popes power to command temporals, and to puni≈øh temporally by way of co√´rtion, which di≈øtinction ≈øeemeth greatly to trouble this Author, becau≈øe he perceiueth, that it ≈øatisfieth the chiefe≈øt Arguments, which are v≈øually brought from the authoritie of many Canons, and from the nature and effects of Excommunication, to prooue, that the Pope hath power, not onely by the priuiledges of Princes, but al≈øo by Chri≈øt his in≈øtitution, and by con≈øequence of his Pa≈øtorall office, to di≈øpo≈øe of temporals, and to inflict temporall puni≈øhments by way of co√´rcion.

3 Secondly, I ≈øhewed, that Mar≈øilius of Padua, whom with other enemies of the Church, Suarez affirmeth to haue fir≈øt impugned this Doctrine of depo≈øing temporall Princes by the Popes ≈øpirituall authoritie, was not by Catholike writers of former times accounted an heretick, for that he did impugne this Doctrine, neither do tho≈øe Authours, who relate Mar≈øilius
his errours, as Ca≈øtro, Prateolus, D. Sanders, and others, note this for one, that the Pope hath not power to depo≈øe Princes; which is an euident ≈øigne, that before this our mi≈øerable age, that Doctrine for the Popes power to depo≈øe Princes, was not accounted by Catholickes to be a point of faith.

4 Thirdly, that from the time of Gregorie the ≈øeuenth, who was the fir≈øt Authour, that cleerely taught this Doctrine, (but after he had fir≈øt put it in practi≈øe) and was the fir≈øt Pope, that, contrarie to the cu≈øtome of his Ance≈øtors (≈øaith Onuphrius) depo≈øed the Roman Emperour (for which cau≈øe he had much adoe to cleere him≈øelf euen with his own friends, as appeareth by the Letter, which Hermannus Bi≈øhop of Mentz, his deare friend, and follower in all ≈øuch his proceedings, wrote vnto him, de≈øiring to be ≈øatisfied herein, and was by Sigebert, who in tho≈øe dayes was greatly e≈øteemed by the wi≈øe≈øt for his ≈øingular vertue, and learning, although Cardinal Baronius, and Cardinall Bellarmine doe without ≈øufficient ground call him a Sci≈ømatick, at that time impeached
of noueltie, not to ≈øay, of here≈øie, for ≈øo bee Sigeberts words) it hath been continually euen to the≈øe our daies contradicted by Catholike Authors, as appeareth by Ioannes Trithemius, Jn Chronico Mona≈øterii Hir. ≈øaug. ad annum 1106. and Iacobus Almainus In lib. a ‚Ä¢ dominio naturali &c. inprobatione conclu≈ø 2 ae. there related, but e≈øpecially by the Kingdome of France, as witne≈ø≈øeth Petrus Pithaeus, In codice libertatum Eccle≈ø. Galli canae. a man greatly commended by Fa: Po≈ø≈øeuine the Ie≈øuit, for his ≈øingular learning and knowledge in Antiquities,In Apparatu verbo Petrus Pithaeus. and it is ≈øufficiently confirmed by the late proceeding at Paris again≈øt the bookes of Card: Bellarmine, Becanus Schulckenius, and now la≈øtly of Suarez, who≈øe booke was for this Doctrine by a ≈øolemne Decree of the Parliament of Paris, and Printed by the Kings Printer, and with the Kings priuiledge condemned, and reprochfully burned the 27. of Iune pa≈øt by the hangman, before the great Staires of the Pallace, and foure of the chiefe≈øt Ie≈øuites of France therein named, were enioyned vnder paine of trea≈øon in their Sermons to exhort the people to the contrarie Doctrine: And doubtle≈ø≈øe this Authour, who in all points followeth the≈øe former mens ≈øteps, if his booke had beene printed in Latine, would haue
quickly perceiued by the fruits of his own labours, whether in France there be any Catholikes, who doe impugne this Doctrine of depo≈øing Princes by the Popes authoritie, or no: And yet this Authour would cunningly per≈øwade the ≈øimpler ≈øort of Catholikes, therby to perplexe their con≈øciences, that I onely am the man, who doe impugne this temporall authoritie of the Pope to depo≈øe Princes; whereas hee cannot be ignorant, that be≈øides mee, many others of our nation, as both the Barclaies, Mr Blackwell, Mr Warmington, Mr. Barret, tho≈øe thirteene Reuerend Prie≈øts, all by publike writings, and many others of the be≈øt learned of our Nation, both Prie≈øts, and lay-men I could name, who are of my opinion; and if it were not for the clamors, threatnings, and violent proceedings of our Aduer≈øaries, (I meane not Prote≈øtants) they vvould publikely profe≈ø≈øe as much as I haue done: and as for the State of France, what opinion they be of, it is manife≈øt. And therefore that Doctrine of ∆≤a≈øquez concerning probable opinions may bee very wel applyed to this my doctrine, how≈øoeuer this Author fal≈øely ≈øuppo≈øing the Doctrine for
the Popes power to depo≈øe Princes to be defined, would gladly per≈øwade our Engli≈øh Catholikes to the contrarie.

5 Fourthly, I ≈øhewed in that booke, that ≈øeeing the Pope is not the Church, but onely a principall member thereof, their is to bee made a great di≈øtinction betweene the facts, and practi≈øes of Popes, and betweene the facts and practi≈øe of the Church: neither is the practi≈øe of many Popes, to bee accounted the practi≈øe of the Church, vnle≈ø≈øe by the vvhole Church it be allowed, as that opinion and practi≈øe for the Popes power to depo≈øe Princes, and to inflict temporall puni≈øhments by way of co√´rtion neuer was: and therefore although it be, and hath beene, the more common opinion of Catholikes for ≈øome ages pa≈øt, that the Pope hath authority to depo≈øe, yet that it is certaine, and not to bee contradicted, but to bee beleeued as a point of faith, and the contrary not to be accounted an opinion, but rather an here≈øie, is altogether fal≈øe. To the Councell of Lateran, which but of late yeares hath been vrged, and that onely by ≈øome few, becau≈øe Suarez did onely barely relate it, and not vrge the wordes
thereof, I did remit him to the Preface of my Apologelicall An≈øwere, wherein I largely di≈øcour≈øed of the Decree of that Councel. But becau≈øe this Author ≈øeemeth to ≈øtand much thereon, as the chiefe pillar and ground of his pretended definition, I will at large in my An≈øwere to his Reply treate of that Councell, and ≈øatisfie all the cauils (which neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øhould bee cleere demon≈øtrations, if this Author did intend to proue his purpo≈øe) vvhich hee hath taken out of D. Singletons, or rather Fa: Le≈øsius his Di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of the Decree of that Councell, and I will ≈øhew, that it cannot be ≈øufficiently proued, fir≈øt, that the Councell by tho≈øe words, temporall Lord, did intend to include Soueraign Princes; ≈øecondly, that although it did by tho≈øe words vnder≈øtand Soueraigne Princes, yet that it did not ≈øuppo≈øe, that the Pope had authoritie to depo≈øe Soueraigne Princes; & thirdly, that although it did ≈øuppo≈øe it, yet it did not ≈øuppo≈øe it as a point of faith, and an vndoubted doctrine, but at the mo≈øt as probable opinion, ≈øo that from the authoritie of this Councel it can not bee conuinced, that it is a point of faith or an vndoubted doctrine, that the
Pope hath authoritie to depo≈øe Soueraign Princes.

6 La≈øtly, thou mai≈øt perceiue (Good Reader) what ≈øtrange paradoxes this Author dare aduenture to maintaine by this, that he blu≈øheth not to affirme, & would cunningly per≈øwade our State, that my manner of handling this controuer≈øie probably, concerning the Popes authoritie to depo≈øe Princes &c. is dangerous & pernicious to his Maie≈øtie, and therefore, that my books de≈øerue to be prohibited, no le≈ø≈øe in England then Rome, and that wi≈øe men in the parts where hee is, doe greatly maruell, how it can ≈øtand with the wi≈øedome of his Maie≈øties Councell to permit them to bee printed and publi≈øhed in England.

7 But if this Author had either ≈øincerely or entirely related my opinion, or el≈øe had put in minde the Reader again≈øt what kinde of Aduer≈øaries I doe oppo≈øe, he would pre≈øently haue perceiued, that it is too apparantly, & ≈øhamefully vntrue, that my manner of handling this que≈øtion probably is dangerous and pernicious to his Maie≈øtie, as this Author doth endeuor to per≈øwade his Maie≈øty, not for any loue that he is knowne to beare vnto the State,
but to the end, by all likelihood, that hee and ≈øuch like violent ≈øpirits, may vvrite more freely, and without being controuled or contradicted by Catholikes, who, as hee is per≈øwaded doe little regard the writings, and opinions of Prote≈øtants concerning this or any other Doctrine. For it may be dangerous to his Maie≈øtie to handle a que≈øtion probably again≈øt one Aduer≈øarie, which will bee nothing dangerous to handle it probably again≈øt an other. As for example, if it were agreed vpon by all Catholikes, that the Pope hath no power to depo≈øe his Maie≈øtie, then it were dangerous to his Maie≈øtie, that any Catholike ≈øhould call this in que≈øtion, and di≈øpute it probably: but if on the contrarie ≈øide, all Catholikes ≈øhould agree in this, that it were certaine, vnque≈øtionable, and a point of faith, that the Pope hath power to depo≈øe his Maie≈øtie, and to ab≈øolue his Subiects of their allegiance, to command them to take armes again≈øt him, &c. then if a Catholike ≈øhould call this in que≈øtion, or, which is all one, di≈øpute it probably, and maintaine that it is not certaine that the Pope hath ≈øuch an authoritie, but it is que≈øtionable,
and probable, that hee hath it not, no man of any ≈øen≈øe, or vnder≈øtanding can affirme, that ≈øuch a manner of di≈øputing this que≈øtion probably again≈øt tho≈øe Aduer≈øaries, who hold it for certaine, can be any way dangerous, or pernicious to his Maie≈øtie.

8 Now behold the manner that I haue taken in handling this Controuer≈øie. Card. Bellarmin, Gretzer, Le≈øsius, Becanus, Suarez, and other Diuines, e≈øpecially of the Society of Ie≈øus, whom this Authour doth in euery ≈øteppe, as though he were their Creature, follow, haue laid this for a ≈øure and vndoubted ground, that it is a point of faith, and to be beleeued as certaine, and vnder paine of eternall damnation by all Catholikes, that the Pope hath power to depo≈øe Princes, to ab≈øolue Subiects from their Allegiance, and thereupon to commaund them to beare Armes, and rai≈øe tumults again≈øt their Prince ≈øo depo≈øed. So that you ≈øee, that they already haue layd the danger, and vndoubted ouerthrow to his Maie≈øties per≈øon and Crowne, if the Pope ≈øhould perchance depo≈øe him, in that they affirme, that all Catholikes are bound in con≈øcience to
for≈øake him, and to fulfill the Popes commaund, to the de≈øtruction of His Maie≈øties per≈øon and State. This Doctrine, to wit; that it is a point of Faith, and vndoubted principle of Catholike Religion, that the Pope hath power to depo≈øe Princes, and to inflict all temporal puni≈øhments by way of coercion, and that all Catholikes are bound in con≈øcience to for≈øake his Maie≈øtie, and to beare Armes again≈øt him, in ca≈øe the Pope ≈øhould depo≈øe him, I haue taken vpon me, for two principall rea≈øons, to impugne, and do not doubt cleerely to maintaine the ≈øame again≈øt the clamours of this Authour, or any other what≈øoeuer. My fir≈øt rea≈øon was, for that it is again≈øt the truth and puritie of the Catholike Church, She being the piller and ground of truth, that doubtfull opinions, and which among Catholikes are onely in Controuer≈øie, and by the Parliament of Paris, haue beene condemned as ≈øcandalous, ≈øeditious, damnable, and Pernitious, ≈øhould be enforced vpon Engli≈øh Catholikes, as an vndoubted doctrine of the Catholike Faith, to the vtter ouerthrow of them≈øelues, and their whole po≈øterity, by meÃÑ who are in no danger to loo≈øe, but
